challengeDetails.title: From EarthData to Action: Cloud Computing with Earth Observation Data for Predicting Cleaner, Safer Skies
challengeDetails.excerpt: NASA’s Tropospheric Emissions: Monitoring of Pollution (TEMPO) mission is revolutionizing air quality monitoring across North America by enabling better forecasts and reducing pollutant exposure. Your challenge is to develop a web-based app that forecasts air quality by integrating real-time TEMPO data with ground-based air quality measurements and weather data, notifying users of poor air quality, and helping to improve public health decisions. Teams are encouraged to utilize new technologies that allow seamless scaling of computing from local devices to cloud systems, enhancing collaboration and streamlining work efficiency. (Earth Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: Sharks from Space
challengeDetails.excerpt: Earth’s ocean is one of the most powerful habitats in our universe, supporting a range of life that sustains ecosystems and habitability across the globe. It is common to measure photosynthetic activity in the ocean from space, but far more challenging to track top predators. Your challenge is to create a mathematical framework for identifying sharks and predicting their foraging habitats using NASA satellite data, and also to suggest a new conceptual model of a tag (a small electronic device that can be attached to an animal to track and study its movement) that could measure not only where sharks are, but also what they are eating, and in real time transmit that data back to users to enable development of predictive models. (Earth Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: BloomWatch: An Earth Observation Application for Global Flowering Phenology
challengeDetails.excerpt: Witness the pulse of life across our planet! From season to season and year to year, Earth’s vegetation is constantly changing, providing critical information on plant species, crops, seasonal effects, pollen sources, and changes in plant phenology (the relationship between seasonal changes and climate and biological phenomena in plants). Your challenge is to harness the power of NASA Earth observations to create a dynamic visual tool that displays and/or detects plant blooming events around the globe—just like pollinators do–and that advances solutions for monitoring, predicting, or managing vegetation. (Earth Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: Embiggen Your Eyes!
challengeDetails.excerpt: While your cell phone screen can display about three million pixels of information and your eye can receive more than ten million pixels, NASA images from space are even bigger! NASA’s space missions continue to push the boundaries of what is technologically possible, providing high-resolution images and videos of Earth, other planets, and space with billions or even trillions of pixels. Your challenge is to create a platform that allows users to zoom in and out on these massive image datasets, label known features, and discover new patterns. (Astrophysics Division)

challengeDetails.title: NASA Farm Navigators: Using NASA Data Exploration in Agriculture
challengeDetails.excerpt: The agriculture community faces the challenge of integrating technology and data to enhance sustainable farming practices. Simulating key farming activities like fertilizing, irrigating, and livestock management using real-world NASA satellite imagery and climate data can enable better understanding of the impacts of these variables on crop production. Your challenge is to create an engaging educational game that effectively utilizes NASA’s open data sets to simulate farming scenarios and enables players to learn how this data can inform innovative, sustainable, agricultural methods. (Earth Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: Will It Rain On My Parade?
challengeDetails.excerpt: If you’re planning an outdoor event—like a vacation, a hike on a trail, or fishing on a lake—it would be good to know the chances of adverse weather for the time and location you are considering. There are many types of Earth observation data that can provide information on weather conditions for a particular location and day of the year. Your challenge is to construct an app with a personalized interface that enables users to conduct a customized query to tell them the likelihood of “very hot,” “very cold,” “very windy,” “very wet,” or “very uncomfortable” conditions for the location and time they specify. (Earth Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: Data Pathways to Healthy Cities and Human Settlements
challengeDetails.excerpt: Climate change brings about new complexities to consider for maintaining the wellbeing of society and the environment in cities. Natural resources, ecosystems, and existing infrastructure all must be monitored to ensure human quality of life remains high. Your challenge is to demonstrate how an urban planner can use NASA Earth observation data to develop smart strategies for city growth that maintain both the wellbeing of people and the environment. (Earth Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: Meteor Madness
challengeDetails.excerpt: A newly identified near-Earth asteroid, "Impactor-2025," poses a potential threat to Earth, but do we have the tools to enable the public and decision makers to understand and mitigate its risks? NASA datasets include information about known asteroids and the United States Geological Survey provides critical information that could enable modeling the effects of asteroid impacts, but this data needs to be integrated to enable effective visualization and decision making. Your challenge is to develop an interactive visualization and simulation tool that uses real data to help users model asteroid impact scenarios, predict consequences, and evaluate potential mitigation strategies. (Planetary Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: A World Away: Hunting for Exoplanets with AI
challengeDetails.excerpt: Data from several different space-based exoplanet surveying missions have enabled discovery of thousands of new planets outside our solar system, but most of these exoplanets were identified manually. With advances in artificial intelligence and machine learning (AI/ML), it is possible to automatically analyze large sets of data collected by these missions to identify exoplanets. Your challenge is to create an AI/ML model that is trained on one or more of the open-source exoplanet datasets offered by NASA and that can analyze new data to accurately identify exoplanets. (Astrophysics Division)

challengeDetails.title: Animation Celebration of Terra Data!
challengeDetails.excerpt: NASA’s oldest daily Earth-viewing satellite – Terra – just turned 25 years old, and with five continuously operating instruments onboard (most taking imagery at the same time), Terra has piled up a LOT of data over the years (over 9,000 days and counting!). This data has the potential to shed light on everything from scientific processes to unique events, all while helping solve problems that affect humans. Your challenge is to use data from any or all of Terra’s five instruments to create an animated product showcasing an Earth science story and emphasizing the impacts to you, your community, and/or the environment. (Earth Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: Stellar Stories: Space Weather Through the Eyes of Earthlings
challengeDetails.excerpt: Although the Sun is 93 million miles away from our planet, solar activity can significantly impact our daily lives. “Space weather”—the variations that occur in the space environment between the Sun and Earth—can impact technologies in space and on Earth. Your challenge is to write and illustrate a digital children’s story that explains what space weather is and the varying impacts it has on different people such as farmers, pilots, astronauts, power grid operators, and the general public. You can tell the story from the perspective of a person impacted by space weather or from the point of view of a solar flare or coronal mass ejection (CME) as it approaches Earth. (Heliophysics Division)

challengeDetails.title: Create Your Own Challenge

Whether you want to create an app, artwork, story, lesson, tool, or explore an innovative way to use NASA data, you set the challenge. challengeDetails.title: Build a Space Biology Knowledge Engine
challengeDetails.excerpt: Enable a new era of human space exploration! NASA has been performing biology experiments in space for decades, generating a tremendous amount of information that will need to be considered as humans prepare to revisit the Moon and explore Mars. Although this knowledge is publicly available, it can be difficult for potential users to find information that pertains to their specific interests. Your challenge is to build a dynamic dashboard that leverages artificial intelligence (AI), knowledge graphs, and/or other tools to summarize a set of NASA bioscience publications and enables users to explore the impacts and results of the experiments these publications describe. (Earth Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: Commercializing Low Earth Orbit (LEO)
challengeDetails.excerpt: As the commercialization of space rapidly accelerates, the future of business in low Earth orbit (LEO) holds incredible potential, but also presents significant operational, regulatory, and environmental challenges. This new economic frontier invites innovative and sustainable approaches to foster long-term viability and responsible execution. Your challenge is to conceptualize and design a scalable, sustainable, business model, accompanied by a prototype, that explores the unique opportunities LEO offers while addressing the complexities of operating in space. (Joint Agency Satellite Division)

challengeDetails.title: Meteor Madness
challengeDetails.excerpt: A newly identified near-Earth asteroid, "Impactor-2025," poses a potential threat to Earth, but do we have the tools to enable the public and decision makers to understand and mitigate its risks? NASA datasets include information about known asteroids and the United States Geological Survey provides critical information that could enable modeling the effects of asteroid impacts, but this data needs to be integrated to enable effective visualization and decision making. Your challenge is to develop an interactive visualization and simulation tool that uses real data to help users model asteroid impact scenarios, predict consequences, and evaluate potential mitigation strategies. (Planetary Science Division)

projectDetails.name: CosmoEX: Simplificando o acesso à pesquisa espacial com IA
projectDetails.summary:
Somos a equipe CosmoEX: Exploradores do Cosmos, e nossa missão é democratizar o acesso ao conhecimento científico, tornando as descobertas da NASA acessíveis a todos. Desenvolvemos uma inteligência artificial conversacional que responde perguntas em linguagem natural com base em artigos, dados e publicações oficiais da NASA.

O CosmoEX funciona como um assistente semelhante ao ChatGPT, mas voltado exclusivamente para conteúdos científicos e espaciais. Ao digitar perguntas como “O que a NASA descobriu sobre buracos negros?”, o usuário recebe respostas contextualizadas e baseadas em fontes verificadas, além do link para o arquivo completo, aproximando a ciência da vida cotidiana.

Nosso sistema foi construído com
projectDetails.details:
Introdução

Em um mundo movido pela informação, o conhecimento científico é uma das ferramentas mais poderosas para o avanço da humanidade. No entanto, o acesso a esse conhecimento ainda é desigual. Diariamente, estudantes, pesquisadores independentes e pequenos cientistas enfrentam grandes barreiras para encontrar e compreender artigos científicos relevantes, um processo demorado, técnico e, muitas vezes, desmotivador.

O CosmoEX nasce com o propósito de democratizar o acesso às pesquisas, transformando a busca por conhecimento em uma experiência simples, intuitiva e acessível.

O problema

A pesquisa científica, apesar de essencial, ainda é vista como inacessível para a maioria. Universitários e pequenos pesquisadores frequentemente gastam horas ou até dias tentando filtrar centenas de artigos em busca de poucos que realmente contribuem para suas hipóteses.

Essa dificuldade em encontrar materiais relevantes não é apenas um desafio técnico, mas também um obstáculo emocional e social. Muitos acabam desistindo de seus projetos por frustração ou por falta de recursos. O resultado é uma perda significativa de potencial intelectual e inovação, especialmente em países em desenvolvimento, onde o acesso à informação científica de qualidade ainda é limitado.

A lacuna

Apesar da imensa disponibilidade de dados e artigos científicos abertos, a ponte entre a informação e quem precisa dela ainda é frágil. As plataformas de pesquisa existentes são complexas e pouco intuitivas.

Em outras palavras, há um abismo entre a curiosidade e o conhecimento, e é justamente essa lacuna que o CosmoEX se propõe a preencher.

Nossa solução

O CosmoEX é uma inteligência artificial conversacional projetada para simplificar e acelerar o acesso a pesquisas científicas, utilizando os dados e artigos disponibilizados pela NASA. Por meio de uma interface semelhante a um chat, o usuário pode fazer perguntas em linguagem natural, por exemplo:

“O que a NASA descobriu sobre buracos negros?”

A IA processa a consulta, busca informações em seu banco de dados, e responde de forma contextualizada e confiável, além do link para o artigo completo.

Com o CosmoEX, estudantes e pesquisadores podem conversar diretamente com o conhecimento, economizando tempo e abrindo novas portas para descobertas.

Como funciona

Detalhes da implementação

Impacto

O CosmoEX tem o potencial de revolucionar o acesso à pesquisa científica, reduzindo drasticamente o tempo de busca por informações relevantes. Ele democratiza o conhecimento, permitindo que estudantes, curiosos e cientistas independentes explorem dados da NASA de forma simples, eliminando barreiras técnicas e linguísticas.

Com o uso do CosmoEX, mais pessoas poderão participar ativamente da construção do conhecimento científico, estimulando o pensamento crítico, a inovação e o interesse pela ciência. Em longo prazo, isso significa uma sociedade mais informada, colaborativa e preparada para resolver desafios globais, exatamente como a NASA sempre inspirou.

Conclusão

O CosmoEX representa o encontro entre tecnologia, curiosidade e propósito.
Mais do que uma ferramenta, é um movimento em prol da democratização da ciência. Ao transformar dados complexos em conhecimento acessível, nosso projeto busca inspirar novas gerações de exploradores, não apenas do espaço, mas do saber.

challengeDetails.title: Sharks from Space
challengeDetails.excerpt: Earth’s ocean is one of the most powerful habitats in our universe, supporting a range of life that sustains ecosystems and habitability across the globe. It is common to measure photosynthetic activity in the ocean from space, but far more challenging to track top predators. Your challenge is to create a mathematical framework for identifying sharks and predicting their foraging habitats using NASA satellite data, and also to suggest a new conceptual model of a tag (a small electronic device that can be attached to an animal to track and study its movement) that could measure not only where sharks are, but also what they are eating, and in real time transmit that data back to users to enable development of predictive models. (Earth Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: From EarthData to Action: Cloud Computing with Earth Observation Data for Predicting Cleaner, Safer Skies
challengeDetails.excerpt: NASA’s Tropospheric Emissions: Monitoring of Pollution (TEMPO) mission is revolutionizing air quality monitoring across North America by enabling better forecasts and reducing pollutant exposure. Your challenge is to develop a web-based app that forecasts air quality by integrating real-time TEMPO data with ground-based air quality measurements and weather data, notifying users of poor air quality, and helping to improve public health decisions. Teams are encouraged to utilize new technologies that allow seamless scaling of computing from local devices to cloud systems, enhancing collaboration and streamlining work efficiency. (Earth Science Division)

Your challenge is to create an AI/ML model that is trained on one or more of the open-source exoplanet datasets offered by NASA and that can analyze new data to accurately identify exoplanets. (Astrophysics Division)

Your challenge is to demonstrate how an urban planner can use NASA Earth observation data to develop smart strategies for city growth that maintain both the wellbeing of people and the environment. (Earth Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: NASA Farm Navigators: Using NASA Data Exploration in Agriculture
challengeDetails.excerpt: The agriculture community faces the challenge of integrating technology and data to enhance sustainable farming practices. Simulating key farming activities like fertilizing, irrigating, and livestock management using real-world NASA satellite imagery and climate data can enable better understanding of the impacts of these variables on crop production. Your challenge is to create an engaging educational game that effectively utilizes NASA’s open data sets to simulate farming scenarios and enables players to learn how this data can inform innovative, sustainable, agricultural methods. (Earth Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: SpaceTrash Hack: Revolutionizing Recycling on Mars
challengeDetails.excerpt: During a hypothetical three-year mission to Mars and back, an eight-person crew would accumulate 12,600 kg of inorganic waste, or trash, including various packaging materials, textiles, and structural materials. This scenario creates a pressing need to recycle available materials, rather than execute the expensive and inefficient processes of transporting additional resources from Earth and/or sending trash back to Earth. As humans prepare to explore unknown worlds in the future, your challenge is to design sustainable systems that could manage, reuse, or recycle inorganic waste (“trash”) that is brought to and/or accumulated on the surface of Mars. (Space Technology Mission Directorate)

challengeDetails.title: Your Home in Space: The Habitat Layout Creator
challengeDetails.excerpt: Space habitats are “homes in space” that keep crew members healthy and able to execute their mission. Whether located on a planetary surface or in space, habitats must support critical functions such as waste management, thermal control, life support, communications, power, stowage, food storage and preparation, medical care, sleep, and exercise. Space habitat concepts can involve a diverse array of materials, geometries, and layouts. Your challenge is to create a visual tool that enables users to define a space habitat’s shape/volume and explore possible layout options. (Exploration Systems Development Mission Directorate)

challengeDetails.title: From EarthData to Action: Cloud Computing with Earth Observation Data for Predicting Cleaner, Safer Skies
challengeDetails.excerpt: NASA’s Tropospheric Emissions: Monitoring of Pollution (TEMPO) mission is revolutionizing air quality monitoring across North America by enabling better forecasts and reducing pollutant exposure. Your challenge is to develop a web-based app that forecasts air quality by integrating real-time TEMPO data with ground-based air quality measurements and weather data, notifying users of poor air quality, and helping to improve public health decisions. Teams are encouraged to utilize new technologies that allow seamless scaling of computing from local devices to cloud systems, enhancing collaboration and streamlining work efficiency. (Earth Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: A World Away: Hunting for Exoplanets with AI
challengeDetails.excerpt: Data from several different space-based exoplanet surveying missions have enabled discovery of thousands of new planets outside our solar system, but most of these exoplanets were identified manually. With advances in artificial intelligence and machine learning (AI/ML), it is possible to automatically analyze large sets of data collected by these missions to identify exoplanets. Your challenge is to create an AI/ML model that is trained on one or more of the open-source exoplanet datasets offered by NASA and that can analyze new data to accurately identify exoplanets. (Astrophysics Division)

challengeDetails.title: Deep Dive: Immersive Data Stories from Ocean to Sky
challengeDetails.excerpt: Satellite observations reveal insights about our dynamic home planet to scientists, but people without a remote sensing background often find the stories within these datasets difficult to access. NASA’s open data policy makes these observations available to everyone—scientists and non-scientists alike. Your challenge is to build a short, immersive, virtual reality (VR) experience that leverages NASA’s Earth observation datasets and visualizations to bring stories about our planet’s oceans to life, connecting a broad audience to this data, its beauty, and its impact. Using visuals, spatial audio, and even interactive elements, your VR experience can enable users to dive deeper into Earth’s unfolding ocean story. (Earth Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: Build a Space Biology Knowledge Engine
challengeDetails.excerpt: Enable a new era of human space exploration! NASA has been performing biology experiments in space for decades, generating a tremendous amount of information that will need to be considered as humans prepare to revisit the Moon and explore Mars. Although this knowledge is publicly available, it can be difficult for potential users to find information that pertains to their specific interests. Your challenge is to build a dynamic dashboard that leverages artificial intelligence (AI), knowledge graphs, and/or other tools to summarize a set of NASA bioscience publications and enables users to explore the impacts and results of the experiments these publications describe. (Earth Science Division)

projectDetails.name: Wind of Changes - Kultive 2025
projectDetails.summary:
Começo dos Trabalhos !
O vento é um fenômeno natural crucial que influencia o clima, transporta sementes, forma ondas no mar e é uma fonte de energia renovável. Ele se forma pelo deslocamento do ar de áreas de alta pressão para as de baixa pressão, causado pelo aquecimento desigual do planeta. O vento pode ser tão forte que atinge centenas de quilômetros por hora em eventos como tornados, e sua força também pode criar o som característico, seja o assobio de turbulências ou o bater de objeto.
No espaço sideral, o vento solar é o movimento através do espaço de gases e partículas carregadas emitidas pelo Sol, enquanto que o vento planetário é a desgaseificação de elementos químicos leves a partir da atmosfera de um planeta em direção ao espaço. Os ventos são geralmente classificados de acordo com a sua escala, rapidez, tipos de forças que os provocam, regiões em que ocorrem e com o seu efeito. Os ventos de maior intensidade observados no sistema solar ocorrem em Neptuno e Saturno.  https://pt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vento
projectDetails.details:
Funcionalidades do aplicativo a ser desenvolvido

Deverá ser fornecido o local e a data da previsão:

Análise de IA:

Utiliza A IA para gerar uma análise textual criativa e espirituosa sobre o clima.

Previsão Baseada em Dados Reais:

A IA consulta a API Open-Meteo para obter dados meteorológicos em tempo real (temperatura, umidade, vento), tornando a análise mais precisa.

O Open-Meteo utiliza uma poderosa combinação de modelos meteorológicos globais (11 km) e de mesoescala (1 km) de renomados serviços meteorológicos nacionais, fornecendo previsões abrangentes com precisão notável.

Não importa onde você esteja no mundo, você pode acessar as previsões meteorológicas mais confiáveis ​​e precisas disponíveis.

Os dados meteorológicos são apresentados em resolução horária, permitindo que você planeje suas atividades com confiança.

Os primeiros dias da previsão se beneficiam de modelos meteorológicos localizados, que oferecem informações altamente detalhadas e precisas. Posteriormente, modelos meteorológicos globais fornecem previsões para até 16 dias. Por meio de integração perfeita, nossas APIs oferecem uma experiência de previsão do tempo horária simples e confiável.

Além disso, os dados são licenciados sob a Atribuição 4.0 Internacional (CC BY 4.0) .

Isso significa que você tem liberdade para compartilhar e adaptar os dados, mesmo para fins comerciais.

Elas são baseadas no protocolo HTTP amplamente adotado e utilizam a simplicidade do formato de dados JSON.

Tudo o que você precisa para começar é um conhecimento básico de coordenadas geográficas,

como fazer solicitações HTTP e trabalhar com dados JSON.

https://open-meteo.com/en/docs

Medidor de "Estraga-Festa":

Exibe a probabilidade (0-100%) de condições adversas como

"Muito Quente", "Muito Frio", "Muito Vento", etc.

Mapa Interativo:

Mostra a localização analisada em um mapa Leaflet, com um marcador que exibe a temperatura e umidade atuais.

Camadas de Satélite:

Integra camadas de satélite da NASA GIBS, permitindo visualizar nuvens (GOES) e precipitação (GPM) em tempo real.

challengeDetails.title: Will It Rain On My Parade?
challengeDetails.excerpt: If you’re planning an outdoor event—like a vacation, a hike on a trail, or fishing on a lake—it would be good to know the chances of adverse weather for the time and location you are considering. There are many types of Earth observation data that can provide information on weather conditions for a particular location and day of the year. Your challenge is to construct an app with a personalized interface that enables users to conduct a customized query to tell them the likelihood of “very hot,” “very cold,” “very windy,” “very wet,” or “very uncomfortable” conditions for the location and time they specify. (Earth Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: Stellar Stories: Space Weather Through the Eyes of Earthlings
challengeDetails.excerpt: Although the Sun is 93 million miles away from our planet, solar activity can significantly impact our daily lives. “Space weather”—the variations that occur in the space environment between the Sun and Earth—can impact technologies in space and on Earth. Your challenge is to write and illustrate a digital children’s story that explains what space weather is and the varying impacts it has on different people such as farmers, pilots, astronauts, power grid operators, and the general public. You can tell the story from the perspective of a person impacted by space weather or from the point of view of a solar flare or coronal mass ejection (CME) as it approaches Earth. (Heliophysics Division)

challengeDetails.title: Meteor Madness
challengeDetails.excerpt: A newly identified near-Earth asteroid, "Impactor-2025," poses a potential threat to Earth, but do we have the tools to enable the public and decision makers to understand and mitigate its risks? NASA datasets include information about known asteroids and the United States Geological Survey provides critical information that could enable modeling the effects of asteroid impacts, but this data needs to be integrated to enable effective visualization and decision making. Your challenge is to develop an interactive visualization and simulation tool that uses real data to help users model asteroid impact scenarios, predict consequences, and evaluate potential mitigation strategies. (Planetary Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: Sharks from Space
challengeDetails.excerpt: Earth’s ocean is one of the most powerful habitats in our universe, supporting a range of life that sustains ecosystems and habitability across the globe. It is common to measure photosynthetic activity in the ocean from space, but far more challenging to track top predators. Your challenge is to create a mathematical framework for identifying sharks and predicting their foraging habitats using NASA satellite data, and also to suggest a new conceptual model of a tag (a small electronic device that can be attached to an animal to track and study its movement) that could measure not only where sharks are, but also what they are eating, and in real time transmit that data back to users to enable development of predictive models. (Earth Science Division)

challengeDetails.excerpt: As the commercialization of space rapidly accelerates, the future of business in low Earth orbit (LEO) holds incredible potential, but also presents significant operational, regulatory, and environmental challenges. This new economic frontier invites innovative and sustainable approaches to foster long-term viability and responsible execution. (Joint Agency Satellite Division)

challengeDetails.title: From EarthData to Action: Cloud Computing with Earth Observation Data for Predicting Cleaner, Safer Skies
challengeDetails.excerpt: NASA’s Tropospheric Emissions: Monitoring of Pollution (TEMPO) mission is revolutionizing air quality monitoring across North America by enabling better forecasts and reducing pollutant exposure. Your challenge is to develop a web-based app that forecasts air quality by integrating real-time TEMPO data with ground-based air quality measurements and weather data, notifying users of poor air quality, and helping to improve public health decisions. Teams are encouraged to utilize new technologies that allow seamless scaling of computing from local devices to cloud systems, enhancing collaboration and streamlining work efficiency. (Earth Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: SpaceTrash Hack: Revolutionizing Recycling on Mars
challengeDetails.excerpt: During a hypothetical three-year mission to Mars and back, an eight-person crew would accumulate 12,600 kg of inorganic waste, or trash, including various packaging materials, textiles, and structural materials. This scenario creates a pressing need to recycle available materials, rather than execute the expensive and inefficient processes of transporting additional resources from Earth and/or sending trash back to Earth. As humans prepare to explore unknown worlds in the future, your challenge is to design sustainable systems that could manage, reuse, or recycle inorganic waste (“trash”) that is brought to and/or accumulated on the surface of Mars. (Space Technology Mission Directorate)

projectDetails.name: Project PowerGeeks
projectDetails.summary:
A página “ISS Experience | NASA Challenge 2025” convida você a viver uma experiência interativa inspirada na Estação Espacial Internacional (ISS). Nela, você pode explorar a Terra como se estivesse na cúpula da ISS, passeando por diferentes lugares e vendo fotos reais tiradas pelos astronautas.

Além disso, é possível personalizar seu próprio astronauta, aprender curiosidades sobre fenômenos naturais e descobertas científicas feitas a partir do espaço, e se divertir em simuladores de treinamento — como o Laboratório de Flutuação Neutra, onde treinam para caminhadas espaciais ou até mesmo missões na Lua.

A página mostra como a ISS é importante para pesquisas que ajudam a humanidade, desde entender melhor o clima até preparar astronautas para as próximas aventuras espaciais. Também oferece links para saber mais nos sites oficiais da NASA e da ISS.

challengeDetails.title: International Space Station 25th Anniversary Apps
challengeDetails.excerpt: Crews onboard the International Space Station have many unique opportunities! They witness breathtaking Earth views from the station’s cupola—known as “the window to the world.” ​​They also experience weightlessness and go outside the station on spacewalks, for which they must train extensively in the Neutral Buoyancy Laboratory (NBL) at the Sonny Carter Training Facility in Houston, Texas. Your challenge is to create a visual tool that not only helps students and the public understand two of the most prominent sensory experiences on the station (sight and weightlessness) through the lens of the cupola and the NBL, but also informs them how these unique experiences benefit humans on Earth. (Space Operations Mission Directorate)

challengeDetails.title: NASA Farm Navigators: Using NASA Data Exploration in Agriculture
challengeDetails.excerpt: The agriculture community faces the challenge of integrating technology and data to enhance sustainable farming practices. Simulating key farming activities like fertilizing, irrigating, and livestock management using real-world NASA satellite imagery and climate data can enable better understanding of the impacts of these variables on crop production. Your challenge is to create an engaging educational game that effectively utilizes NASA’s open data sets to simulate farming scenarios and enables players to learn how this data can inform innovative, sustainable, agricultural methods. (Earth Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: A World Away: Hunting for Exoplanets with AI
challengeDetails.excerpt: Data from several different space-based exoplanet surveying missions have enabled discovery of thousands of new planets outside our solar system, but most of these exoplanets were identified manually. With advances in artificial intelligence and machine learning (AI/ML), it is possible to automatically analyze large sets of data collected by these missions to identify exoplanets. Your challenge is to create an AI/ML model that is trained on one or more of the open-source exoplanet datasets offered by NASA and that can analyze new data to accurately identify exoplanets. (Astrophysics Division)

challengeDetails.title: Build a Space Biology Knowledge Engine
challengeDetails.excerpt: Enable a new era of human space exploration! NASA has been performing biology experiments in space for decades, generating a tremendous amount of information that will need to be considered as humans prepare to revisit the Moon and explore Mars. Although this knowledge is publicly available, it can be difficult for potential users to find information that pertains to their specific interests. Your challenge is to build a dynamic dashboard that leverages artificial intelligence (AI), knowledge graphs, and/or other tools to summarize a set of NASA bioscience publications and enables users to explore the impacts and results of the experiments these publications describe. (Earth Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: Will It Rain On My Parade?
challengeDetails.excerpt: If you’re planning an outdoor event—like a vacation, a hike on a trail, or fishing on a lake—it would be good to know the chances of adverse weather for the time and location you are considering. There are many types of Earth observation data that can provide information on weather conditions for a particular location and day of the year. Your challenge is to construct an app with a personalized interface that enables users to conduct a customized query to tell them the likelihood of “very hot,” “very cold,” “very windy,” “very wet,” or “very uncomfortable” conditions for the location and time they specify. (Earth Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: Meteor Madness
challengeDetails.excerpt: A newly identified near-Earth asteroid, "Impactor-2025," poses a potential threat to Earth, but do we have the tools to enable the public and decision makers to understand and mitigate its risks? NASA datasets include information about known asteroids and the United States Geological Survey provides critical information that could enable modeling the effects of asteroid impacts, but this data needs to be integrated to enable effective visualization and decision making. Your challenge is to develop an interactive visualization and simulation tool that uses real data to help users model asteroid impact scenarios, predict consequences, and evaluate potential mitigation strategies. (Planetary Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: BloomWatch: An Earth Observation Application for Global Flowering Phenology
challengeDetails.excerpt: Witness the pulse of life across our planet! From season to season and year to year, Earth’s vegetation is constantly changing, providing critical information on plant species, crops, seasonal effects, pollen sources, and changes in plant phenology (the relationship between seasonal changes and climate and biological phenomena in plants). Your challenge is to harness the power of NASA Earth observations to create a dynamic visual tool that displays and/or detects plant blooming events around the globe—just like pollinators do–and that advances solutions for monitoring, predicting, or managing vegetation. (Earth Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: Through the Radar Looking Glass: Revealing Earth Processes with SAR
challengeDetails.excerpt: Like Alice in Wonderland, let’s travel down the rabbit hole to reveal a world that looks like our planet Earth… but not quite! Using synthetic aperture radar (SAR), we can image the world by emitting radar pulses toward Earth and recording the energy that is reflected back after the signals interact with Earth's surface. Your challenge is to download multi-frequency or multi-polarization SAR data for an interesting study area of your choice –e.g., your hometown, a tropical wetland, ice sheet, forest wildfire, flooded neighborhood, volcano eruption, etc.—and use that data to develop hypotheses about the physical drivers operating there. (Earth Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: Stellar Stories: Space Weather Through the Eyes of Earthlings
challengeDetails.excerpt: Although the Sun is 93 million miles away from our planet, solar activity can significantly impact our daily lives. “Space weather”—the variations that occur in the space environment between the Sun and Earth—can impact technologies in space and on Earth. Your challenge is to write and illustrate a digital children’s story that explains what space weather is and the varying impacts it has on different people such as farmers, pilots, astronauts, power grid operators, and the general public. You can tell the story from the perspective of a person impacted by space weather or from the point of view of a solar flare or coronal mass ejection (CME) as it approaches Earth. (Heliophysics Division)

challengeDetails.title: Sharks from Space
challengeDetails.excerpt: Earth’s ocean is one of the most powerful habitats in our universe, supporting a range of life that sustains ecosystems and habitability across the globe. It is common to measure photosynthetic activity in the ocean from space, but far more challenging to track top predators. Your challenge is to create a mathematical framework for identifying sharks and predicting their foraging habitats using NASA satellite data, and also to suggest a new conceptual model of a tag (a small electronic device that can be attached to an animal to track and study its movement) that could measure not only where sharks are, but also what they are eating, and in real time transmit that data back to users to enable development of predictive models. (Earth Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: Your Home in Space: The Habitat Layout Creator
challengeDetails.excerpt: Space habitats are “homes in space” that keep crew members healthy and able to execute their mission. Whether located on a planetary surface or in space, habitats must support critical functions such as waste management, thermal control, life support, communications, power, stowage, food storage and preparation, medical care, sleep, and exercise. Space habitat concepts can involve a diverse array of materials, geometries, and layouts. Your challenge is to create a visual tool that enables users to define a space habitat’s shape/volume and explore possible layout options. (Exploration Systems Development Mission Directorate)

challengeDetails.title: Deep Dive: Immersive Data Stories from Ocean to Sky
challengeDetails.excerpt: Satellite observations reveal insights about our dynamic home planet to scientists, but people without a remote sensing background often find the stories within these datasets difficult to access. NASA’s open data policy makes these observations available to everyone—scientists and non-scientists alike. Your challenge is to build a short, immersive, virtual reality (VR) experience that leverages NASA’s Earth observation datasets and visualizations to bring stories about our planet’s oceans to life, connecting a broad audience to this data, its beauty, and its impact. Using visuals, spatial audio, and even interactive elements, your VR experience can enable users to dive deeper into Earth’s unfolding ocean story. (Earth Science Division)

Using synthetic aperture radar (SAR), we can image the world by emitting radar pulses toward Earth and recording the energy that is reflected back after the signals interact with Earth's surface. Your challenge is to download multi-frequency or multi-polarization SAR data for an interesting study area of your choice –e.g., your hometown, a tropical wetland, ice sheet, forest wildfire, flooded neighborhood, volcano eruption, etc.—and use that data to develop hypotheses about the physical drivers operating there. (Earth Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: Will It Rain On My Parade?
challengeDetails.excerpt: If you’re planning an outdoor event—like a vacation, a hike on a trail, or fishing on a lake—it would be good to know the chances of adverse weather for the time and location you are considering. There are many types of Earth observation data that can provide information on weather conditions for a particular location and day of the year. Your challenge is to construct an app with a personalized interface that enables users to conduct a customized query to tell them the likelihood of “very hot,” “very cold,” “very windy,” “very wet,” or “very uncomfortable” conditions for the location and time they specify. (Earth Science Division)

projectDetails.name: Project Name: UrbanMinds
projectDetails.summary: We created a website that recommends the best sustainable urban development methods for the user’s selected location. The platform focuses on enhancing residents’ quality of life while supporting a fast and sustainable city growth. It is important because sustainable urban development is one of the most pressing issues today, since most urban areas worldwide lack an ecologically sound growth, which is vital for improving people's quality of life and other essential aspects.
projectDetails.details: We created a website that features a map integrating NASA Earth Science data to recommend the best sustainable urban development methods for the user’s selected location (currently limited to a few cities). The platform focuses on enhancing residents’ quality of life while supporting fast and sustainable city growth. We intend to bring benefits in people's quality of life and urbanization, since it can help with usefull information about pollution, helping the development of cities without destroying nature. We used NASA Worldview, NASA GIBS (Global Imagery Browse Services), OpenStreetMap, Web Map Service (WMS), Canva, Visual Studio Code, Google Docs, Vercel. The coding languages used are JavaScript, HTML, CSS and Python, and Artificial Intelligences were used to assist the coding.
projectDetails.aiReferences: We used AIs to various purposes, including research, writing improvement and to assist our AI coding and website coding (Gemini, Grok and ChatGPT).

challengeDetails.title: Data Pathways to Healthy Cities and Human Settlements
challengeDetails.excerpt: Climate change brings about new complexities to consider for maintaining the wellbeing of society and the environment in cities. Natural resources, ecosystems, and existing infrastructure all must be monitored to ensure human quality of life remains high. Your challenge is to demonstrate how an urban planner can use NASA Earth observation data to develop smart strategies for city growth that maintain both the wellbeing of people and the environment. (Earth Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: Commercializing Low Earth Orbit (LEO)
challengeDetails.excerpt: As the commercialization of space rapidly accelerates, the future of business in low Earth orbit (LEO) holds incredible potential, but also presents significant operational, regulatory, and environmental challenges. This new economic frontier invites innovative and sustainable approaches to foster long-term viability and responsible execution. Your challenge is to conceptualize and design a scalable, sustainable, business model, accompanied by a prototype, that explores the unique opportunities LEO offers while addressing the complexities of operating in space. (Joint Agency Satellite Division)

projectDetails.name: Project VoyIAger
projectDetails.summary:
O Exoplanet Hunter 2025 é um projeto desenvolvido para o NASA Space Apps Challenge, cujo objetivo é detectar e estimar a habitabilidade de exoplanetas usando técnicas de inteligência artificial. A solução utiliza um classificador Random Forest treinado com dados do NASA Exoplanet Archive, com balanceamento de classes via SMOTE, e permite previsões individuais ou em lote. Uma interface interativa em Streamlit exibe métricas como matriz de confusão e importância de features, além de visualizações auxiliares.

Essa abordagem é relevante porque automatiza e escala a análise de grandes volumes de dados astronômicos, ajudando a priorizar candidatos promissores para investigações futuras. Ademais, integra ciência de dados e astrofísica para promover descobertas em exoplanetologia.
projectDetails.details:
O Exoplanet Hunter 2025 é uma aplicação que utiliza aprendizado de máquina para identificar e avaliar a habitabilidade potencial de exoplanetas com base em dados reais do NASA Exoplanet Archive. O sistema emprega um modelo de classificação Random Forest treinado e balanceado com SMOTE, capaz de prever se um planeta pode sustentar condições habitáveis.

O projeto oferece uma interface interativa em Streamlit, onde o usuário pode enviar dados de planetas, visualizar resultados, interpretar métricas de desempenho (como matriz de confusão e importância das features) e compreender o processo preditivo.

Os principais benefícios incluem a automação da triagem de exoplanetas, redução do tempo de análise e apoio a decisões de priorização para estudos futuros. O impacto pretendido é ampliar o alcance da pesquisa astronômica e estimular o uso de IA acessível para exploração científica.

Ferramentas e tecnologias: Python, scikit-learn, pandas, matplotlib, Streamlit, GitHub, Google Colab e Gamma App (para o slide).

A criatividade do projeto está na integração prática de ciência de dados e astrofísica, tornando a detecção de exoplanetas mais intuitiva e educativa. A equipe considerou interpretabilidade, usabilidade, transparência e o uso ético de IA.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
Nosso projeto faz uso de ferramentas de IA como ChatGPT (OpenAI GPT-5), Grok e GitHub Copilot para auxiliar na refatoração de código, otimização de lógica e geração de documentação e textos explicativos.
Essas ferramentas não geraram os dados científicos nem o modelo preditivo principal, mas foram usadas para acelerar o desenvolvimento, melhorar a clareza do código e preparar a apresentação.
A Gamma App (também com recursos de IA) foi usada para criar o slide de forma visual e organizada.
Todo conteúdo gerado por IA foi revisado, ajustado e validado pela equipe humana.
projectDetails.projectReferences:
[Streamlit (App Framework)](https://streamlit.io/)
[scikit-learn (Machine Learning Library)](https://scikit-learn.org/)
[Gamma App (Presentation Tool)](https://gamma.app/)
[GitHub Repository - Exoplanet Hunter 2025](https://github.com/GermanoAugustoFB/exoplanet-hunter-2025)

challengeDetails.title: A World Away: Hunting for Exoplanets with AI
challengeDetails.excerpt: Data from several different space-based exoplanet surveying missions have enabled discovery of thousands of new planets outside our solar system, but most of these exoplanets were identified manually. With advances in artificial intelligence and machine learning (AI/ML), it is possible to automatically analyze large sets of data collected by these missions to identify exoplanets. Your challenge is to create an AI/ML model that is trained on one or more of the open-source exoplanet datasets offered by NASA and that can analyze new data to accurately identify exoplanets. (Astrophysics Division)

challengeDetails.title: From EarthData to Action: Cloud Computing with Earth Observation Data for Predicting Cleaner, Safer Skies
challengeDetails.excerpt: NASA’s Tropospheric Emissions: Monitoring of Pollution (TEMPO) mission is revolutionizing air quality monitoring across North America by enabling better forecasts and reducing pollutant exposure. Your challenge is to develop a web-based app that forecasts air quality by integrating real-time TEMPO data with ground-based air quality measurements and weather data, notifying users of poor air quality, and helping to improve public health decisions. Teams are encouraged to utilize new technologies that allow seamless scaling of computing from local devices to cloud systems, enhancing collaboration and streamlining work efficiency. (Earth Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: NASA Farm Navigators: Using NASA Data Exploration in Agriculture
challengeDetails.excerpt: The agriculture community faces the challenge of integrating technology and data to enhance sustainable farming practices. Simulating key farming activities like fertilizing, irrigating, and livestock management using real-world NASA satellite imagery and climate data can enable better understanding of the impacts of these variables on crop production. Your challenge is to create an engaging educational game that effectively utilizes NASA’s open data sets to simulate farming scenarios and enables players to learn how this data can inform innovative, sustainable, agricultural methods. (Earth Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: Stellar Stories: Space Weather Through the Eyes of Earthlings
challengeDetails.excerpt: Although the Sun is 93 million miles away from our planet, solar activity can significantly impact our daily lives. “Space weather”—the variations that occur in the space environment between the Sun and Earth—can impact technologies in space and on Earth. Your challenge is to write and illustrate a digital children’s story that explains what space weather is and the varying impacts it has on different people such as farmers, pilots, astronauts, power grid operators, and the general public. You can tell the story from the perspective of a person impacted by space weather or from the point of view of a solar flare or coronal mass ejection (CME) as it approaches Earth. (Heliophysics Division)
